newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Reynolds, Russia firm, in aluminium foil deal.
newsitem.headline: Reynolds, Russia firm, in aluminium foil deal.

text.p: Russian aluminium foil maker Sayanal and Reynolds International of the United States plan to set up a joint venture to sell Russian-made foil to domestic and foreign users, a top company official said on Wednesday.
"Reynolds will find orders for us," said Sayanal chief executive Oleg Deripaska, who also heads Sayansky Alyuminievy Zavod, Russia's third-largest aluminium producer.
The Sayansk factory has a controlling interest in Sayanal, a joint venture with Reynolds International (a Reynolds Metals Co unit) and Italy's Fata.
A copy of a document signed by officials from Sayanal and Reynolds said the two sides would work to improve quality to meet the needs of cigarette packagers in Russia and abroad.
The goal, the document said, is "to develop... cigarette packaging technology which would meet the requirements of Philip Morris and other leader tobacco companies."
A Reynolds official in Moscow declined to comment.
Sayanal, which has a modern factory located on the southern Siberian steppe, does not yet make foil thin enough to meet cigarette packaging standards.

Deripaska said the joint venture would open eight offices across Russia to persuade Russian industrial consumers -- which annually import 50,000 tonnes of packaging materials, over half of them made of aluminium -- to buy some locally-made aluminium.
He said that while domestic demand for aluminium was soft, it held good long-term potential, especially among producers of chocolate, milk and other consumer goods.
"We will (eventually) try to sell everything in Russia," he said.
Sayanal plans to produce at least 3,000 tonnes per month of foil products, including packaging materials and household foil, by 2000, up from its current output of 500 tonnes a month.
Foil production at Sayanal would reach 1,400 tonnes per month by 1997, Deripaska said, adding, "We need to compete with Western production."
He said domestic primary aluminium consumption was 250,000 tonnes in 1995 -- about half the 550,000 level reported for 1995 by the Russian State Metallurgy Committee.
A 1995 report commissioned by the International Primary Aluminium Institute said Russian domestic aluminium consumption fell from 2.76 million tonnes in 1989 to 657,000 tonnes in 1993.
Fast-moving consumer goods manufacturers in Russia have only recently begun to revamp their packaging to compete with Western imports.
While Moscow has seen a construction boom that producers say could spur demand for aluminium, overall demand is still far below levels seen in recent years.
